analyzed: adya sapta aha kālagataḥ rudrakaḥ rāma putraḥ
translated: Rudraka, the son of Rāma, has been dead for seven days.

original: tasya me bhikṣava etadabhūt mahāhānirvartate rudrakasya rāmaputrasya /🔽ya imameva supraṇītaṃ dharmamaśrutvā kālagataḥ /
analyzed: tasya me bhikṣavaḥ etat abhūt mahā hāniḥ vartate rudrakasya rāmaputrasya  yaḥ imam eva su praṇītam dharmam a śrutvā kālagataḥ
translated: Monks, I thought this: There is great loss for Rudraka, the son of Rāma.🔽He has died without hearing this well-taught Dharma.

analyzed: saced asau imam dharmam aśroṣyat ājñāsyat
translated: If he had heard this Dharma, he would have understood it.

analyzed: tasmai ca aham prathamam dharma deśayiṣyam
translated: I would have taught him the Dharma first.

analyzed: na ca mām sa vyaheṭhayiṣyat
translated: He would not have harmed me.

original: punarapi bhikṣavastathāgatasyaitadabhūt ko 'nyaḥ sattvaḥ śuddhaḥ suvineyaḥ pūrvavadyāvanna ca dharmadeśanāṃ viheṭhayediti /
analyzed: punar api bhikṣavaḥ tathāgatasya etat abhūt kaḥ nyaḥ sattvaḥ śuddhaḥ su vineyaḥ pūrvavat yāvat na ca dharma deśanām viheṭhayet iti
translated: Again, monks, the Tathāgata thought: Which other being is pure, easy to train, and so on, up to not harming my teaching of the Dharma?

original: tato bhikṣavastathāgatasyaitadabhavat ayaṃ khalvapyārāḍaḥ kālāpaḥ śuddho yāvanna ca me dharmadeśanāṃ viheṭhayediti /
analyzed: tatas bhikṣavaḥ tathāgatasya etat abhavat ayam khalu api ārāḍaḥ kālāpaḥ śuddhaḥ yāvat na ca me dharma deśanām viheṭhayet iti
translated: Then, monks, the Tathāgata thought: This Ārāḍa Kālāma is pure, and so on, up to not harming my teaching of the Dharma.

analyzed: samanvāharati sma bhikṣavaḥ tathāgataḥ kutra asau etarhi iti
translated: Monks, the Tathāgata reflected: Where is he now?

analyzed: samanvāharan ca ajñāsīt adya trīṇi ahāni kālagatasya iti
translated: And he knew that it had been three days since he had died.

original: śuddhāvāsakāyikā api ca devatā enamarthaṃ tathāgatasyārocayanti sma evametadbhagavan /
analyzed: śuddhāvāsa kāyikāḥ api ca devatāḥ enam artham tathāgatasya ārocayanti sma evam etat bhagavan
translated: The gods of the Pure Abodes also informed the Thus-Gone One of this matter, saying, It is so, Blessed One.

analyzed: evam etat sugata
translated: It is so, Sugata.

analyzed: adya tri aham kālagatasya ārāḍasya kālāpasya
translated: It has been three days since Ārāḍa Kālāma died.

analyzed: tatas tathāgatasya etat abhavat mahā hāniḥ vartate arāḍasya kālāpasya
translated: Then the Thus-Gone One thought, There is a great loss for Ārāḍa Kālāma.

original: ya imamevaṃ supraṇītaṃ dharmamaśrutvā kālagata iti //
analyzed: yaḥ imam evam su praṇītam dharmam a śrutvā kālagataḥ iti
translated: He has died without hearing this well-taught Dharma.

original: punarapi bhikṣavastathāgatasyaitadabhūt kaḥ khalvanyaḥ sattvaḥ śuddhaḥ svākāro yāvanna ca me dharmadeśanāṃ viheṭhayediti //
analyzed: punar api bhikṣavaḥ tathāgatasya etat abhūt kaḥ khalu anyaḥ sattvaḥ śuddhaḥ su ākāraḥ yāvat na ca me dharma deśanām viheṭhayet iti
translated: Again, monks, the Thus-Gone One thought, What other being is pure, well-natured, and will not reject my teaching of the Dharma?

original: atha khalu bhikṣavastathāgatasyaitadabhavat te khalu pañcakā bhadravargīyāḥ śuddhāḥ svākārāḥ suvijñāpakāḥ suviśodhakā mandarāgadoṣamohā aparokṣavijñānāḥ
analyzed: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ tathāgatasya etat abhavat te khalu pañcakāḥ bhadravargīyāḥ śuddhāḥ su ākārāḥ su vijñāpakāḥ su viśodhakāḥ manda rāga doṣa mohāḥ aparokṣa vijñānāḥ
translated: Then, monks, the Thus-Gone One thought, Those five companions are pure, well-natured, and will not reject my teaching of the Dharma. They have little desire, anger, and ignorance, and have unobstructed understanding.

analyzed: te śravaṇāt dharmasya parihīyante
translated: They are declining due to not hearing the Dharma.

analyzed: taiḥ ca aham duṣkara caryām caran upasthitaḥ bhūvam
translated: And they attended on me while I was practicing austerities.

analyzed: te mayā dharmam deśitam ājñāsyanti
translated: They will understand the Dharma that I teach.

analyzed: na ca me ha viheṭhayiṣyanti
translated: And they will not harm me.”

analyzed: vaidya
translated: physician

original: atha khalu bhikṣavastathāgatasyaitadabhavat yannvahaṃ pañcakebhyo bhadravargīyebhyaḥ prathamaṃ dharmaṃ deśayeyam //
analyzed: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ tathāgatasya etat abhavat yat nu aham pañcakebhyaḥ bhadravargīyebhyaḥ prathamam dharmam deśayeyam
translated: Then, monks, this occurred to the Thus-Gone One: “Let me first teach the Dharma to the five companions.”

original: atha khalu bhikṣavastathāgatasya punaretadabhavat kasminnetarhi pañcakā bhadravargīyāḥ prativasanti /
analyzed: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ tathāgatasya punar etat abhavat kasmin etarhi pañcakāḥ bhadravargīyāḥ prativasanti
translated: Then, monks, this again occurred to the Thus-Gone One: “Where are the five companions staying now?”

original: atha tathāgataḥ sarvāvantaṃ lokaṃ buddhacakṣuṣā vyavalokayan paśyati sma /
analyzed: atha tathāgataḥ sarvāvantam lokam buddha cakṣuṣā vyavalokayan paśyati sma
translated: Then the Thus-Gone One, surveying the entire world with his Buddha-eye, saw

original: adrākṣītpañcakān bhadravargīyān vārāṇasyāṃ viharata ṛṣipatane mṛgadāve /
analyzed: adrākṣīt pañcakān bhadravargīyān vārāṇasyām viharataḥ ṛṣipatane mṛgadāve
translated: the five ascetics staying in Vārāṇasī, in the Deer Park at Ṛṣivadana.

original: dṛṣṭvā ca tathāgatasyaitadabhavat yannvahaṃ pañcakebhyo bhadravargīyebhyaḥ sarvaprathamaṃ dharmaṃ deśayeyam /
analyzed: dṛṣṭvā ca tathāgatasya etat abhavat yat nu aham pañcakebhyaḥ bhadravargīyebhyaḥ sarva prathamam dharmam deśayeyam
translated: Having seen them, this occurred to the Thus-Gone One: “Let me first teach the Dharma to the five companions.

original: te hi mama sarvaprathamaṃ dharmaṃ deśitamājñāsyanti /
analyzed: te hi mama sarva prathamam dharmam deśitam ājñāsyanti
translated: They will understand the Dharma that I teach for the first time.

analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ
translated: Why is that?

original: caritāvino hi te bhikṣavaḥ suparipaṇḍitaśukladharmāṇo mokṣamārgābhimukhā nibandhāpanītāḥ //
analyzed: caritāvinaḥ hi te bhikṣavaḥ su paripaṇḍita śukla dharmāṇaḥ mokṣa mārga abhimukhāḥ nibandha apanītāḥ
translated: Those monks had practiced well and were thoroughly trained in the bright qualities. They were oriented toward the path of liberation and had removed their bonds.

original: atha khalu bhikṣavastathāgata evamanuvicintya bodhimaṇḍādutthāya trisāhasramahāsāhasraṃ
analyzed: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ tathāgataḥ evam anuvicintya bodhimaṇḍāt utthāya tri sāhasra mahā sāhasram
translated: Then, monks, the Thus-Gone One, having reflected in this way, rose from the seat of awakening and shook the great trichiliocosm.

original: lokadhātuṃ saṃprakampyānupūrveṇa magadheṣu caryāṃ caran kāśiṣu janapadeṣu cārikāṃ prakrāmat /
analyzed: lokadhātum saṃprakampya anupūrveṇa magadheṣu caryām caran kāśiṣu janapadeṣu cārikām prakrāmat
translated: He then proceeded in due course through the Magadha country, wandering and traveling through the Kāśi country.

original: atha gayāyāṃ bodhimaṇḍasya cāntarādanyatama ājīvako 'drākṣīttathāgataṃ dūrata evāgacchantam /
analyzed: atha gayāyām bodhimaṇḍasya ca antarāt anyatamaḥ ājīvakaḥ drākṣīt tathāgatam dūratas eva āgacchantam
translated: Now, in between Gayā and the seat of awakening, a certain Ājīvika saw the Thus-Gone One coming from afar.

analyzed: dṛṣṭvā ca punar yena tathāgataḥ tena upajagāma
translated: Having seen him, he approached the Thus-Gone One.

analyzed: upetya ekānte sthāt
translated: Having approached, he stood to one side.

original: ekānte sthitaśca bhikṣava ājīvakastathāgatena sārdhaṃ vividhāṃ saṃmodanīṃ kathāṃ kṛtvā evamāha viprasannāni te āyuṣman gautama indriyāṇi
analyzed: ekānte sthitaḥ ca bhikṣavaḥ ājīvakaḥ tathāgatena sārdham vividhām saṃmodanīm kathām kṛtvā evam āha viprasannāni te āyuṣman gautamaḥ indriyāṇi
translated: Standing to one side, monks, that Ājīvika, having exchanged various pleasant and polite greetings with the Thus-Gone One, said this: Your faculties are clear, Venerable Gautama,

original: pariśuddhaḥ paryavadātaḥ pītanirbhāsaśca te chavivarṇaḥ tadyathāpi nāma śāradaṃ kālaṃ pāṇḍuravarṇaṃ prabhāsvaraṃ pītanirbhāsaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: pariśuddhaḥ paryavadātaḥ pīta nirbhāsaḥ ca te chavi varṇaḥ tat yathā api nāma śāradam kālam pāṇḍura varṇam prabhāsvaram pīta nirbhāsam bhavati
translated: Your skin has a pure, clear, and yellow glow, just like a ripe autumn leaf in the autumn season, which is bright, pure, clear, and has a yellow glow.

original: evameva bhavato gautamasya pariśuddhānīndriyāṇi pariśuddhaṃ mukhamaṇḍalaṃ paryavadātam /
analyzed: evam eva bhavataḥ gautamasya pariśuddhāni indriyāṇi pariśuddham mukha maṇḍalam paryavadātam
translated: Just so, O Gautama, your faculties are pure, your facial complexion is pure and clear.

original: tadyathāpi nāma tālaphalasya pakvasya samanantaravṛntacyutasya bandhanāśrayaḥ pītanirbhāso bhavati pariśuddhaḥ paryavadātaḥ /
analyzed: tat yathā api nāma tāla phalasya pakvasya samanantara vṛnta cyutasya bandhana āśrayaḥ pīta nirbhāsaḥ bhavati pariśuddhaḥ paryavadātaḥ
translated: Just as a ripe palm fruit, immediately after being detached from its stalk, has a yellow glow that is pure and clear, which is the basis of its bondage.

original: evameva bhavato gautamasya pariśuddhānīndriyāṇi pariśuddhaṃ mukhamaṇḍalaṃ paryavadātam /
analyzed: evam eva bhavataḥ gautamasya pariśuddhāni indriyāṇi pariśuddham mukha maṇḍalam paryavadātam
translated: Just so, O Gautama, your faculties are pure, your facial complexion is pure and clear.

original: tadyathāpi nāma jāmbūnadavarṇaniṣkaḥ ulkāmukhaprakṛṣṭo dakṣiṇakarmāraputreṇa suparikarmakṛtaḥ
analyzed: tat yathā api nāma jāmbūnada varṇa niṣkaḥ ulkāmukha prakṛṣṭaḥ dakṣiṇa karmāra putreṇa su parikarma kṛtaḥ
translated: Just as a Jambūnada gold ornament, well-worked by a skilled goldsmith's son,

original: pāṇḍukambalopanikṣipto varṇavān bhavati pariśuddhaḥ paryavadātaḥ pītanirbhāso 'tīva prabhāsvaraḥ /
analyzed: pāṇḍu kambala upanikṣiptaḥ varṇavān bhavati pariśuddhaḥ paryavadātaḥ tīva prabhāsvaraḥ
translated: placed on a white woolen cloth, becomes even more colorful, pure, clear, and has a yellow glow, shining with great brilliance.

analyzed: evam eva bhavataḥ gautamasya viprasannāni indriyāṇi
translated: Just so, O Gautama, your faculties are clear and bright.

analyzed: pariśuddhaḥ tvac varṇaḥ
translated: Your skin color is pure.

analyzed: paryavadātam mukha maṇḍalam
translated: Your face is radiant.

analyzed: kasmin āyuṣman gautama brahmacaryam uṣyate
translated: Where, Venerable Gautama, is the holy life to be practiced?

analyzed: evam ukte bhikṣavaḥ tathāgataḥ tam ājīvakam gāthayā pratyabhāṣata
translated: When this was said, monks, the Thus-Gone One replied to the Ājīvika in verse:

original: ācāryo na hi me kaścitsadṛśo me na vidyate /
analyzed: ācāryaḥ na hi me kaścid sadṛśaḥ me na vidyate
translated: I have no teacher, none equal to me exists.

analyzed: ekaḥ ham asmi saṃbuddhaḥ śītībhūtaḥ nirāśravaḥ
translated: I am the only one who is fully enlightened, cooled off, and free from defilements.

analyzed: saḥ vocat arham khalu gautamam ātmānam prātijānīṣe
translated: He said, Gautama, you claim to be an Arhat.

analyzed: tathāgataḥ vocat
translated: The Thus-Gone One said:

analyzed: aham eva araham loke śāstā hi aham anuttaraḥ
translated: I alone am the Arhat in the world, I am the unsurpassed Teacher.

analyzed: sa deva asura gandharve na asti me prati pudgalaḥ
translated: Among gods, demons, and Gandharvas, there is no one equal to me.

original: so 'vocat jinaṃ khalu gautama mātmānaṃ pratijānīṣe /
analyzed: saḥ vocat jinam khalu gautama mā ātmānam pratijānīṣe
translated: He said, Gautama, you claim to be a Jina.

analyzed: tathāgataḥ vocat
translated: The Thus-Gone One said:

original: jinā hi mādṛśā jñeyā ye prāptā āśravakṣayam /
analyzed: jināḥ hi mādṛśāḥ jñeyāḥ ye prāptāḥ āśrava kṣayam
translated: Those like me should be known as Jinas, who have attained the destruction of defilements.

original: jitā me pāpakā dharmāstenopaga jino hyaham // / //
analyzed: jitāḥ me pāpakāḥ dharmāḥ tena upaga jinaḥ hi aham
translated: I have conquered evil dharmas, therefore I am a Jina.

analyzed: vaidya
translated: physician

analyzed: saḥ vocat kva tarhi āyuṣman gautama gamiṣyasi
translated: He said, Where, Venerable Gautama, will you go?

analyzed: tathāgataḥ vocat
translated: The Thus-Gone One said:

original: vārāṇasīṃ gamiṣyāmi gatvā vai kāśināṃ purīm /
analyzed: vārāṇasīm gamiṣyāmi gatvā vai kāśinām purīm
translated: I will go to Vārāṇasī, having gone to the city of Kāśi,

analyzed: andha bhūtasya lokasya kartāsmi a sadṛśām prabhām
translated: I will make a light unlike any other for the world, which is blind.

original: vārāṇasīṃ gamiṣyami gatvā vai kāśināṃ purīm /
analyzed: vārāṇasīm gamiṣyami gatvā vai kāśinām purīm
translated: I will go to Vārāṇasī, and having gone to the city of Kāśi,

analyzed: śabda hīnasya lokasya tāḍayiṣye mṛta dundubhim
translated: I will beat the drum of immortality for the world, which is devoid of sound.

original: vārāṇasīṃ gamiṣyāmi gatvā vai kāśināṃ purīm /
analyzed: vārāṇasīm gamiṣyāmi gatvā vai kāśinām purīm
translated: I will go to Vārāṇasī, and having gone to the city of Kāśi,

analyzed: dharma cakram pravartiṣye lokeṣu aprativartitam
translated: I will turn the wheel of Dharma that has never been turned in the world.

original: tadbhaviṣyasi gautama ityuktvā sa ājīvako dakṣiṇāmukhaḥ prākrāmat /
analyzed: tat bhaviṣyasi gautamaḥ iti uktvā saḥ ājīvakaḥ dakṣiṇā mukhaḥ prākrāmat
translated: Gautama, it will be so. Having said this, the Ājīvika departed facing south.

analyzed: tathāgataḥ pi uttarā mukhaḥ prākrāmat
translated: The Tathāgata also departed facing north.

original: iti hi bhikṣavastathāgato gayāyāṃ sudarśanena nāgarājena nimantrito 'bhut vāsena bhaktena ca /
analyzed: iti hi bhikṣavaḥ tathāgataḥ gayāyām sudarśanena nāga rājena nimantritaḥ bhuj vāsena bhaktena ca
translated: Thus, monks, the Tathāgata was invited by the nāga king Sudarśana to stay and eat in Gayā.

analyzed: tatas tathāgataḥ rohitavastum agamat
translated: Then the Tathāgata went to Rohitavastu.

analyzed: tasmāt urubilvā kalpam tasmāt aṇālam agamat
translated: From there he went to Urubilvākalpa, and from there to Āṇā.

analyzed: tatas sārathi puram
translated: Then to Sārathipura.

original: eṣu ca sarveṣu bhikṣavastathāgato gṛhapatibhirbhaktena vāsena copanimantryamāṇo 'nupūrveṇa gaṅgāyā nadyāstīramupāgamat //
analyzed: eṣu ca sarveṣu bhikṣavaḥ tathāgataḥ gṛhapatibhiḥ bhaktena vāsena ca upanimantryamāṇaḥ nupūrveṇa gaṅgāyāḥ nadyāḥ tīram upāgamat
translated: In all these places, monks, the Tathāgata, being invited by the householders to stay and eat, gradually reached the bank of the river Ganges.

original: tena khalu punarbhikṣavaḥ samayena gaṅgā mahānadī suparipūrṇā samatīrthakā vahati sma //
analyzed: tena khalu punar bhikṣavaḥ samayena gaṅgā mahā nadī su paripūrṇā sama tīrthakā vahati sma
translated: Monks, at that time the great river Ganges was full and flowed to the shores.

analyzed: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ tathāgataḥ nāvika samīpam upāgamat pāra saṃtaraṇāya
translated: Monks, then the Thus-Gone One approached a ferryman to cross to the other shore.

analyzed: sa prāha prayaccha gautama tarapaṇyam
translated: He said, Gautama, pay the ferry fee.

original: na me 'sti mārṣa tarapaṇyamityuktvā tathāgato vihāyasā pathā tīrātparaṃ tīramagamat /
analyzed: na me sti mārṣa tarapaṇyam iti uktvā tathāgataḥ vihāyasā pathā tīrāt param tīram agamat
translated: The Thus-Gone One replied, I do not have the ferry fee, and then went to the other shore by flying through the air.

original: tataḥ sa nāvikastaṃ dṛṣṭvātīva vipratisāryabhūt evaṃvidho dakṣiṇīyo mayā na tārita iti /
analyzed: tatas sa nāvikaḥ tam dṛṣṭvā atīva vipratisārī abhūt evaṃvidhaḥ dakṣiṇīyaḥ mayā na tāritaḥ iti
translated: Then the ferryman, seeing that, was extremely remorseful, thinking, I have not ferried across such a worthy one.

original: hā kaṣṭamiti kṛtvā mūrchitaḥ pṛthivyāṃ patitaḥ /
analyzed: hā kaṣṭam iti kṛtvā mūrchitaḥ pṛthivyām patitaḥ
translated: Saying, Alas, what a shame! he fainted and fell to the ground.

original: tata enāṃ prakṛtiṃ nāviko rājñe bimbisārāya ārocayāmāsa śramaṇaḥ svāmi gautamastarapaṇyaṃ yācamāno nāsti tarapaṇyamityuktvā vihāyasā atastīrātparaṃ 🔽tīraṃ gata iti /
analyzed: tatas enām prakṛtim nāvikaḥ rājñe bimbisārāya ārocayāmāsa śramaṇaḥ svāmi gautamaḥ tarapaṇyam yācamānaḥ na asti tarapaṇyam iti uktvā vihāyasā atas tīrāt param  tīram gataḥ iti
translated: Then the ferryman reported this matter to King Bimbisāra, saying, Lord, the ascetic Gautama, when asked for the ferry fee, said he did not have the ferry fee and went to the other shore by flying through the air from this shore.

original: tacchrutvā tadagreṇa rājñā bimbisāreṇa sarvapravrajitānāṃ tarapaṇyamutsṛṣṭamabhavat //
analyzed: tat śrutvā tad agreṇa rājñā bimbisāreṇa sarva pravrajitānām tarapaṇyam utsṛṣṭam abhavat
translated: Having heard that, from then on the ferry fee was waived for all renunciants by King Bimbisāra.

original: iti hi bhikṣavastathāgato 'nupūrveṇa janapadacaryāṃ caran yena vārāṇasī mahānagarī tenopasaṃkrāmat /
analyzed: iti hi bhikṣavaḥ tathāgataḥ nupūrveṇa janapada caryām caran yena vārāṇasī mahā nagarī tena upasaṃkrāmat
translated: Monks, in this way the Thus-Gone One, traveling through the countryside in stages, arrived at the great city of Vārāṇasī.

original: upasaṃkramya kālyameva nivāsya pātracīvaramādāya vārāṇasīṃ mahānagarīṃ piṇḍāya prāvikṣat /
analyzed: upasaṃkramya kālyam eva nivāsya pātra cīvaram ādāya vārāṇasīm mahā nagarīm piṇḍāya prāvikṣat
translated: Having arrived, he dressed in the morning, took his bowl and his robe, and entered the great city of Vārāṇasī for alms.

original: tasyāṃ piṇḍāya caritvā kṛtabhaktakṛtyaḥ paścādbhaktapiṇḍapātrapratikrāntaḥ yena ṛṣipatano mṛgadāvo yena ca pañcakā bhadravargīyāstenopasaṃkrāmati
analyzed: tasyām piṇḍāya caritvā kṛta bhakta kṛtyaḥ paścāt bhakta piṇḍa pātra pratikrāntaḥ yena ṛṣipatanaḥ mṛgadāvaḥ yena ca pañcakāḥ bhadravargīyāḥ tena upasaṃkrāmati  /
translated: Having gone for alms there, after his meal, when he had returned from his alms round, he went to the Deer Park in the Ṛṣipatana grove, to where the group-of-five monks were staying.

analyzed: sma
translated: He approached them.

original: adrākṣuḥ khalu punaḥ pañcakā bhadravargīyāstathāgataṃ dūrata evāgacchantam /
analyzed: adrākṣuḥ khalu punar pañcakāḥ bhadravargīyāḥ tathāgatam dūratas eva āgacchantam
translated: The group-of-five monks saw the Thus-Gone One coming from a distance.

original: dṛṣṭvā ca kriyābandhamakārṣuḥ eṣa sa āyuṣmantaḥ śramaṇo gautama āgacchati sma śaithiliko bāhulikaḥ pradhānavibhraṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: dṛṣṭvā ca kriyā bandham akārṣuḥ eṣa saḥ āyuṣmantaḥ śramaṇaḥ gautamaḥ āgacchati sma śaithilikaḥ bāhulikaḥ pradhāna vibhraṣṭaḥ
translated: And when they saw him, they made an agreement: “Venerable friends, here comes the ascetic Gautama, who has given up his striving and reverted to a life of indulgence.

original: anena khalvapi tayāpi tāvatpūrvikayā duṣkaracaryayā na śakitaṃ kiṃciduttarimanuṣyadharmādalamāryajñānadarśanaviśeṣaṃ sākṣātkartum /
analyzed: anena khalu api tayā api tāvat pūrvikayā duṣkara caryayā na śakitam kiṃcid uttari manuṣya dharmāt alam ārya jñāna darśana viśeṣam sākṣātkartum
translated: By that former practice of austerities, he was not able to attain any special state of knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, any higher knowledge regarding the human or divine worlds.

analyzed: kim punar etarhi audārikam āhāram āharan sukhallikā yogam anuyuktaḥ viharan
translated: How much more so now, when he eats coarse food, is devoted to the practice of pleasure,

analyzed: abhavyaḥ khalu eṣa śaithilikaḥ bāhulikaḥ
translated: and is unfit for the practice of laxity and abundance.

analyzed: na asya kenacid pratyudgantavyam na pratyutthātavyam
translated: No one should rise up to greet him, or offer him a seat.

original: na pātracīvaraṃ pratigrahītavyaṃ nāśanaṃ dātavyaṃ na pānīyaṃ paribhogyaṃ na pādapratiṣṭhānaṃ sthāpayitvātiriktānyāsanāni /
analyzed: na pātra cīvaram pratigrahītavyam na aśanam dātavyam na pānīyam paribhogyam na pāda pratiṣṭhānam sthāpayitvā atiriktāni āsanāni
translated: He should not be given a bowl or robes, nor should he be given food, water, or a footrest, except for extra seats.

analyzed: vaktavyam ca vaidya
translated: And he should be told:

analyzed: saṃvidyante imāni āyuṣman gautama atiriktāni āsanāni
translated: Venerable Gautama, these extra seats are here.

analyzed: saced ākāṅkṣasi niṣīda iti
translated: If you wish, you may sit.

analyzed: āyuṣmān tvā ajñānakauṇḍinyaḥ cittena adhivāsayati sma
translated: The Venerable Ājñātakauṇḍinya mentally assented,

analyzed: vācā ca na pratikṣipati sma
translated: but did not verbally reject it.

original: yathā yathā ca bhikṣavastathāgato yena pañcakā bhadravargīyāstenopasaṃkrāmati sma /
analyzed: yathā yathā ca bhikṣavaḥ tathāgataḥ yena pañcakāḥ bhadravargīyāḥ tena upasaṃkrāmati sma
translated: Monks, as the Tathāgata approached the five ascetic companions,

original: tathā tathā te svakasvakeṣvāsaneṣu na ramante sma /
analyzed: tathā tathā te svaka svakeṣu āsaneṣu na ramante sma
translated: they were not pleased with their own seats.

analyzed: utthātu kāmāḥ abhūvan
translated: They wanted to get up.

original: tadyathāpi nāma pakṣī śakuniḥ pañjaragataḥ syāt /
analyzed: tat yathā api nāma pakṣī śakuniḥ pañjara gataḥ syāt
translated: It was as if a bird in a cage

analyzed: tasya ca pañjara gatasya adhas gniḥ dagdhaḥ bhavet
translated: And below the cage, fire would be burning.

analyzed: saḥ agni saṃtaptaḥ tvaritam ūrdhvam utpatitu kāmaḥ bhavet pratretu kāmaḥ ca
translated: He, being heated by the fire, would quickly want to fly up and escape.

original: evameva yathā yathā tathāgataḥ pañcakānāṃ bhadravargīyāṇāṃ sakāśamupasaṃkrāmati sma /
analyzed: evam eva yathā yathā tathāgataḥ pañcakānām bhadravargīyāṇām sakāśam upasaṃkrāmati sma
translated: In the same way, as the Tathāgata approached the five ascetic companions,

original: tathā tathā pañcakā bhadravargīyāḥ svakasvakeṣvāsaneṣu na ramante sma /
analyzed: tathā tathā pañcakāḥ bhadravargīyāḥ svaka svakeṣu āsaneṣu na ramante sma
translated: in the same way the five ascetic companions were not delighted in their own seats.

analyzed: utthātu kāmāḥ abhūvan
translated: They wanted to rise up.

original: tatkasmāt / na sa kaścitsattvaḥ sattvanikāye saṃvidyate yastathāgataṃ dṛṣṭvā āsanānna pratyuttiṣṭhet /
analyzed: tat kasmāt na sa kaścid sattvaḥ sattva nikāye saṃvidyate yaḥ tathāgatam dṛṣṭvā āsanāt na pratyuttiṣṭhet
translated: Why is that? There is no being whatsoever in the assembly of beings who, having seen the Tathāgata, would not rise from their seat.

original: yathā yathā ca tathāgataḥ pañcakān bhadravargīyānupasaṃkrāmati sma /
analyzed: yathā yathā ca tathāgataḥ pañcakān bhadravargīyān upasaṃkrāmati sma
translated: And as the Tathāgata approached the five ascetic companions,

original: tathā tathā pañcakā bhadravargīyāstathāgatasya śriyaṃ tejaścāsahamānā āsanebhyaḥ prakampyamānāḥ sarve kriyākāraṃ bhittvā cotthāyāsanebhyaḥ /🔽kaścitpratyudgacchati sma /
analyzed: tathā tathā pañcakāḥ bhadravargīyāḥ tathāgatasya śriyam tejaḥ ca asahamānāḥ āsanebhyaḥ prakampyamānāḥ sarve kriyākāram bhittvā ca utthāya āsanebhyaḥ  kaścid pratyudgacchati sma
translated: in the same way the five ascetic companions, unable to bear the splendor and brilliance of the Tathāgata, shaken from their seats, all breaking their agreement, rose from their seats.🔽Some went to meet him.

analyzed: kaścid pratyudgamya pātra cīvaram pratigṛhṇāti sma
translated: Some, having gone to meet him, received his alms bowl and robes.

analyzed: kaścid āsanam upanāmayati sma
translated: someone offered him a seat.

analyzed: kaścid pāda pratiṣṭhāpanam kaścid pāda prakṣālana udakam upasthāpayati sma
translated: Someone set out water for washing his feet, and someone else a foot stool.

original: evaṃ cāvocat svāgataṃ te āyuṣman gautama /
analyzed: evam ca avocat svāgatam te āyuṣman gautama
translated: He said, “Welcome, Venerable Gautama!

analyzed: svāgatam te āyuṣman gautam
translated: Welcome, Venerable Gautama!

analyzed: niṣīda idam āsanam prajñaptam
translated: Please sit on this seat that has been prepared.”

analyzed: nyaṣīdat khalu api bhikṣavaḥ tathāgataḥ prajñapte eva āsane
translated: Monks, the Thus-Gone One sat down on the seat that had been prepared.

original: pañcakā pi bhadravargīyāste tathāgatena sārdhaṃ vividhāṃ saṃmodanīṃ saṃrañjanīṃ kathāṃ kṛtvaikānte niṣeduḥ /🔽ekānte niṣaṇṇāśca te pañcakā bhadravargīyāstathāgatametadavocan viprasannāni te āyuṣman gautamendriyāṇi /
analyzed: pañcakāḥ pi bhadravargīyāḥ te tathāgatena sārdham vividhām saṃmodanīm saṃrañjanīm kathām kṛtvā ekānte niṣeduḥ  ekānte niṣaṇṇāḥ ca te pañcakāḥ bhadravargīyāḥ tathāgatam etat avocan viprasannāni te āyuṣman gautama indriyāṇi
translated: The five ascetic companions also sat down to one side after engaging in various pleasant and joyful conversations with the Thus-Gone One.

analyzed: pariśuddhaḥ chavi varṇaḥ iti hi sarvam pūrvavat
translated: After sitting to one side, the five ascetic companions said this to the Thus-Gone One: “Venerable Gautama, your faculties are clear and your complexion is pure and radiant. In short, all is as before.

analyzed: tat asti te āyuṣman gautama kaścid uttari manuṣya dharmāṃdalam ārya jñāna darśana viśeṣaḥ sākṣātkṛtaḥ
translated: Venerable Gautama, have you realized any higher-than-human, noble, and true knowledge and insight?”

original: evamukte bhikṣavastathāgataḥ pañcakān bhadravargīyānevamāha mā yūyaṃ bhikṣavastathāgatamāyuṣmadvādena samudācariṣṭa /
analyzed: evam ukte bhikṣavaḥ tathāgataḥ pañcakān bhadravargīyān evam āha mā yūyam bhikṣavaḥ tathāgatam āyuṣmat vādena samudācariṣṭa
translated: Monks, when this was said, the Thus-Gone One said to the five ascetic companions: Monks, do not address the Thus-Gone One as 'venerable sir.'

analyzed: mā vaḥ bhūt dīrgharātram arthāya hitāya sukhāya
translated: Do not let it be for your long-term harm, benefit, well-being, and happiness.

original: amṛtaṃ mayā bhikṣavaḥ sākṣātkṛto 'mṛtagāmī ca mārgaḥ /
analyzed: amṛtam mayā bhikṣavaḥ sākṣātkṛtaḥ mṛta gāmī ca mārgaḥ
translated: Monks, I have directly realized the deathless, and I have realized the path leading to the deathless.

analyzed: buddhaḥ ham asmi bhikṣavaḥ sarvajñaḥ sarva darśī śītībhūtaḥ na āśravaḥ
translated: Monks, I am the Buddha, all-knowing, all-seeing, cooled off, free from defilements,

analyzed: vaśī sarva dharmeṣu
translated: in control of all dharmas.

analyzed: dharmam aham bhikṣavaḥ deśayiṣyāmi
translated: Monks, I will teach the Dharma.

analyzed: āśu gacchata śṛṇuta pratipadyadhvam
translated: Go quickly, listen, practice.

original: śrotamavadadhata ahamavavadāmyanuśāsmi /🔽yathā mayā samyagavavaditāḥ samyaganuśiṣṭā yūyamapyāśravāṇāṃ cetovimuktaṃ prajñāvimuktiṃ🔽ca dṛṣṭa eva dharme sākṣātkṛtvopasaṃpadya pravedayiṣyatha kṣīṇā no jātiruṣitaṃ ca brahmacaryam /
analyzed: aham avavadāmi anuśāsmi  yathā mayā samyak avavaditāḥ samyak anuśiṣṭāḥ yūyam api āśravāṇām cetaḥ vimuktam prajñā vimuktim  ca dṛṣṭe eva dharme sākṣātkṛtvā upasaṃpadya pravedayiṣyatha kṣīṇā naḥ jātiḥ uṣitam ca brahmacaryam
translated: Pay attention, I will instruct and admonish.🔽As I properly instruct and admonish you, you will directly realize and attain the liberation of the mind through the destruction of the taints, and the liberation by wisdom in this very life,

analyzed: kṛtam karaṇīyam
translated: and declare: 'Our births are destroyed, the holy life has been accomplished, what had to be done has been done,

analyzed: na aparam iti atas nyadbhavam prajānāmaḥ iti
translated: there will be no more of this or that state.'

original: nanu ca yuṣmākaṃ bhikṣava etadabhūt ayaṃ khalvāyuṣmanta āgacchati śramaṇo gautamaḥ śaithiliko bāhulikaḥ pradhānavibhraṣṭa iti pūrvavat /
analyzed: nanu ca yuṣmākam bhikṣavaḥ etat abhūt ayam khalu āyuṣmantaḥ āgacchati śramaṇaḥ gautamaḥ śaithilikaḥ bāhulikaḥ pradhāna vibhraṣṭaḥ iti pūrvavat
translated: But, monks, you thought, This venerable one is coming, the ascetic Gautama, who is lax, luxurious, and fallen from his striving, as before.

analyzed: saced ākāṅkṣasi niṣīda iti
translated: If you wish, sit down.

original: teṣāṃ ca ehi bhikṣava ityukte yatkiṃcittīrthikaliṅgaṃ tīrthikadhvajaḥ /
analyzed: teṣām ca ehi bhikṣavaḥ iti ukte yat kiṃcid tīrthika liṅgam tīrthika dhvajaḥ
translated: And when they were told, Come, monks! whatever was the mark of a tīrthika, the flag of a tīrthika,

analyzed: tad kṣaṇam eva antaraghāt
translated: all that disappeared at that very moment.

analyzed: tri cīvaram pātram ca prādurabhūt
translated: The three robes and alms bowl appeared.

analyzed: tadanu chinnāḥ ca keśāḥ
translated: Their hair and beards were cut.

analyzed: tat yathā api nāma varṣa śata upasaṃpannasya bhikṣoḥ īryāpathaḥ saṃvṛttaḥ bhuj
translated: Their deportment became like that of a monk who had been ordained for one hundred years.

analyzed: sā eva ca teṣām pravrajyā abhūt sā eva upasaṃpad bhikṣu bhāvaḥ
translated: That itself was their going forth, that their higher ordination, that their state of being a monk.

original: atha khalu bhikṣavastasyāṃ velāyāṃ pañcakā bhadravargīyā bhikṣavastathāgatasya caraṇayornipatyātyayaṃ deśayanti sma /
analyzed: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ tasyām velāyām pañcakāḥ bhadravargīyāḥ bhikṣavaḥ tathāgatasya caraṇayoḥ nipatya atyayam deśayanti sma
translated: Then, monks, at that time the five ascetic companions threw themselves at the feet of the Thus-Gone One and confessed their wrongdoing.

original: tathāgatasyāntike śāstṛsaṃjñāṃ premaṃ ca prasādaṃ ca gauravaṃ cotpādayanti sma /
analyzed: tathāgatasya antike śāstṛ saṃjñām premam ca prasādam ca gauravam ca utpādayanti sma
translated: They generated the perception of the Thus-Gone One as a teacher, love, faith, and respect.

original: gauravajātāśca bahuvicitrapuṣkariṇyāṃ tathāgatasya snānaparikarma kurvanti sma /
analyzed: gaurava jātāḥ ca bahu vicitra puṣkariṇyām tathāgatasya snāna parikarma kurvanti sma
translated: Out of respect, they performed various acts of service for the Thus-Gone One in the lotus pond.

analyzed: snāna pratyuttīrṇasya vaidya
translated: Filled with reverence, they prepared a bath for the Thus-Gone One in the pond with its many kinds of beautiful flowers.

original: ca bhikṣavastathāgatasyaitadabhavat kasmin khalu pūrvakaistathāgatairarhadbhiḥ samyaksaṃbuddhairniṣadya dharmacakraṃ pravartitam /
analyzed: ca bhikṣavaḥ tathāgatasya etat abhavat kasmin khalu pūrvakaiḥ tathāgataiḥ arhadbhiḥ samyaksaṃbuddhaiḥ niṣadya dharmacakram pravartitam
translated: After the bath, the monks, the Thus-Gone One had this thought: Where did the previous thus-gone ones, the worthy ones, the perfect buddhas, sit and turn the wheel of Dharma?

analyzed: yasmin ca bhikṣavaḥ pṛthivī pradeśe pūrvakaiḥ tathāgataiḥ arhadbhiḥ dharmacakram pravartitam abhūt
translated: Monks, in whatever place the previous thus-gone ones, the worthy ones, the perfect buddhas turned the wheel of Dharma,

analyzed: atha tasmin pṛthivī pradeśe sapta ratna mayam āsana sahasram prādurabhūt
translated: in that place a thousand seats made of the seven precious substances appeared.

original: atha tathāgataḥ pūrvakāṇāṃ tathāgatānāṃ gauraveṇa trīṇyāsanāni pradakṣiṇīkṛtya siṃha iva nirbhīścaturtha āsane paryaṅkamābhujya niṣīdati sma
analyzed: atha tathāgataḥ pūrvakāṇām tathāgatānām gauraveṇa trīṇi āsanāni pradakṣiṇīkṛtya siṃhaḥ iva nirbhīḥ caturthe āsane paryaṅkam ābhujya niṣīdati sma
translated: Then, out of reverence for the previous thus-gone ones, the Thus-Gone One circumambulated the three seats and sat down cross-legged on the fourth seat, fearless like a lion.

original: pañcakā api bhikṣavastathāgatasya pādau śirobhirabhivandya tathāgatasya purato niṣeduḥ //
analyzed: pañcakāḥ api bhikṣavaḥ tathāgatasya pādau śirobhiḥ abhivandya tathāgatasya puratas niṣeduḥ
translated: The five monks also bowed their heads at the feet of the Thus-Gone One and sat in front of him.

original: atha khalu bhikṣavastasyāṃ velāyāṃ tathārūpāṃ kāyātprabhāṃ tathāgataḥ prāmuñcadyayā prabhayā ayaṃ trisāhasramahāsāhasro lokadhāturmahatāvabhāsena 🔽sphuṭo 'bhūt /
analyzed: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ tasyām velāyām tathārūpām kāyāt prabhām tathāgataḥ prāmuñcat yayā prabhayā ayam tri sāhasra mahā sāhasraḥ lokadhātuḥ mahatā avabhāsena  sphuṭaḥ bhūt
translated: Monks, at that time the Thus-Gone One emitted from his body a light such that this great trichiliocosm was filled with a great radiance.

original: tena cāvabhāsena yā api lokāntarikā aghā aghasphuṭā andhakāratamisrā yatremau candrasūryau
analyzed: tena ca avabhāsena yāḥ api loka āntarikāḥ aghāḥ agha sphuṭāḥ andhakāra tamisrāḥ yatra imau candra sūryau
translated: By that light, even the dark spaces between worlds, where the sun and moon,

original: evaṃmaharddhikāvevaṃ mahānubhāvāvevaṃ maheśākhyau ābhayā ābhāṃ varṇenaṃ varṇaṃ tejasā
analyzed: evam maharddhikau evam mahā anubhāvau evam maheśākhyau ābhayā ābhām varṇenaṃ varṇam tejasā
translated: so powerful and majestic, with such great splendor,

analyzed: tejaḥ na abhitapataḥ na abhivirocataḥ
translated: radiance, and light, cannot be seen, were illuminated.

original: tatra ye sattvā upapannāste svakasvakamapi bāhuṃ prasāritaṃ na paśyanti sma /
analyzed: tatra ye sattvāḥ upapannāḥ te svaka svakam api bāhum prasāritam na paśyanti sma
translated: The beings born there could see even their own outstretched arms.

original: tatrāpi tasmin samaye mahata udārasyāvabhāsasya loke prādurbhāvo 'bhut /
analyzed: tatra api tasmin samaye mahataḥ udārasya avabhāsasya loke prādurbhāvaḥ bhuj
translated: At that time, a great and vast light appeared in the world.

original: ye ca tatra sattvā upapannāste tenāvabhāsena parisphuṭāḥ samānā anyonyaṃ paśyanti sma /
analyzed: ye ca tatra sattvāḥ upapannāḥ te tena avabhāsena parisphuṭāḥ samānāḥ anyonyam paśyanti sma
translated: The beings born there, illuminated by that light, saw each other and

analyzed: anyonyam saṃjānante sma
translated: recognized each other.

original: evaṃ cāhuḥ anye 'pi kila bhoḥ sattvā ihopapannāḥ /
analyzed: evam ca āhuḥ anye kila bhoḥ sattvāḥ iha upapannāḥ
translated: They said, So it is, friends! Other beings have also been born here!

original: anye 'pi kila bhoḥ sattvā ihopapannāḥ iti /
analyzed: anye pi kila bhoḥ sattvāḥ iha upapannāḥ iti
translated: “Other beings have also been reborn here.”🔽And this great trichiliocosm shook in six ways, with eighteen great signs:

original: ayaṃ ca trisāhasramahāsāhasro lokadhātuḥ ṣaḍvikāramaṣṭādaśamahānimittamabhūt akampat prākampat saṃprākampat /🔽avedhat prāvedhat saṃprāvedhat /🔽acalat prācalat saṃprācalat /
analyzed: ayam ca tri sāhasra mahā sāhasraḥ lokadhātuḥ ṣaṣ vikāram aṣṭādaśa mahā nimittam abhūt akampat prākampat saṃprākampat  avedhat prāvedhat saṃprāvedhat  acalat prācalat saṃprācalat
translated: it quivered, quivered strongly, and quivered intensely;🔽it trembled, trembled strongly, and trembled intensely;🔽it shook, shook strongly, and shook intensely;

analyzed: akṣubhyat prākṣubhyat saṃprākṣubhyat  araṇat prāraṇat saṃprāraṇat
translated: it quaked, quaked strongly, and quaked intensely;🔽it roared, roared strongly, and roared intensely;

original: agarjat prāgarjat saṃprāgarjat /🔽ante 'vanamati sma /🔽madhye unnamati sma /🔽madhye 'vanamati sma ante unnamati sma /
analyzed: agarjat prāgarjat saṃprāgarjat  ante vanamati sma  madhye unnamati sma  madhye vanamati sma ante unnamati sma
translated: it rose up and then fell down;🔽it rose up in the middle and fell down at the edges;

original: pūrvasyāṃ diśyavanamati sma /🔽paścimāyāṃ diśyunnamati sma /🔽paścimāyāṃ diśyavanamati sma /
analyzed: pūrvasyām diśi avanamati sma  paścimāyām diśi unnamati sma  paścimāyām diśi avanamati sma
translated: it rose up at the edges and fell down in the middle;🔽it rose up in the east and fell down in the west;

original: pūrvasyāṃ diśyunnamati sma /🔽dakṣiṇasyāṃ diśyavanamati sma /🔽uttarasyāṃ diśyunnamati sma /🔽uttarasyāṃ diśyavanamati sma /
analyzed: pūrvasyām diśi unnamati sma  dakṣiṇasyām diśi avanamati sma  uttarasyām diśi unnamati sma  uttarasyām diśi avanamati sma
translated: it rose up in the west and fell down in the east;🔽it rose up in the south and fell down in the north;

analyzed: dakṣiṇasyām diśi unnamati sma
translated: it rose up in the north and fell down in the south.

original: tasmiṃśca samaye harṣaṇīyāstoṣaṇīyāḥ premaṇīyāḥ prasādanīyā avalokanīyāḥ prahlādanīyā nirvarṇanīyā aprativarṇanīyā asecanīyā apratikūlā anuttrāsakarāḥ
analyzed: tasmin ca samaye harṣaṇīyāḥ toṣaṇīyāḥ premaṇīyāḥ prasādanīyāḥ avalokanīyāḥ prahlādanīyāḥ nirvarṇanīyāḥ aprativarṇanīyāḥ asecanīyāḥ a pratikūlāḥ an uttrāsa karāḥ  /

analyzed: śabdāḥ śrūyante sma

translated: And it is not possible to count all those supreme beings who have come here from the ten directions.

original: adhyeṣi śākyakulanandana dharmacakre prahvā kṛtāñjalipuṭāścaraṇau nipatya // / //
analyzed: adhyeṣi śākya kula nandana dharmacakre prahvā kṛta añjali puṭā caraṇau nipatya
translated: You request the joy of the Śākya clan to turn the wheel of Dharma, bowing with palms joined, falling at his feet.

original: yā bodhimaṇḍi prakṛtā ca surairviyūhā yā vā viyūha kṛta sarvajinātmajebhiḥ /
analyzed: yā bodhimaṇḍi prakṛtā ca suraiḥ viyūhā yā vā viyūha kṛta sarva jina ātmajebhiḥ
translated: The array made by the gods at the seat of awakening, or the array made by all the Victorious Ones' offspring,

original: sā sarva saṃsthita viyūha ti dharmacakre paripūrṇakalpa bhaṇamānu kṣayaṃ na gacchet // / //
analyzed: dharma cakre paripūrṇa kalpa kṣayam na gacchet
translated: All the arrays of the Dharma wheel would be exhausted if I were to speak for a full eon, but not so for the Dharma wheel of the Tathāgata.

original: trisahasri loki gaganaṃ sphuṭa devasaṃghaiḥ dharaṇītalaṃ asurakinnaramānuṣaiśca /
analyzed: tri sahasri loki gaganam deva saṃghaiḥ dharaṇī talam asura kinnara mānuṣaiḥ ca
translated: The sky of the trichiliocosm is filled with hosts of gods, the earth's surface with asuras, kinnaras, and humans.

original: utkāsaśabdu napi śrūyati tanmuhūrtaṃ sarvi prasannamanaso jinamabhyudīkṣan // / //
analyzed: tat muhūrtam sarvi prasanna manasaḥ jinam abhyudīkṣan
translated: Not even a sound of coughing is heard at that moment; all, with joyful minds, gaze up at the Victor.

analyzed: vaidya
translated: Vidy

original: iti hi bhikṣavastathāgato rātryāḥ prathame yāme tūṣṇībhāvenādhivāsayati sma /
analyzed: iti hi bhikṣavaḥ tathāgataḥ rātryāḥ prathame yāme tūṣṇībhāvena adhivāsayati sma
translated: Thus, monks, the Tathāgata silently assented during the first watch of the night.

original: rātryā madhyame yāme saṃrañjanīyāṃ kathāṃ pravartayati sma /
analyzed: rātryāḥ madhyame yāme saṃrañjanīyām kathām pravartayati sma
translated: During the middle watch of the night, he engaged in delightful conversation.

original: rātryāḥ paścime yāme pañcakān bhadravargīyānāmantryaitadavocat dvāvimau bhikṣavaḥ pravrajitasyāntāvakramau /
analyzed: rātryāḥ paścime yāme pañcakān bhadravargīyān āmantrya etat avocat dvau imau bhikṣavaḥ pravrajitasya anta avakramau
translated: During the last watch of the night, he addressed the five ascetic companions, saying, Monks, these are the two extremes that a renunciant should not approach.

original: yaśca kāmeṣu kāmasukhallikā yogo hīno grāmyaḥ pārthagjaniko nālamāryo 'narthopasaṃhito
analyzed: yaḥ ca kāmeṣu kāma su khallikā yogaḥ hīnaḥ grāmyaḥ pārthagjanikaḥ na alam āryaḥ
translated: The practice of pleasure in sensual desires, which is base, vulgar, common, ignoble, and unbeneficial,

original: nāyatyāṃ brahmacaryāya na nirvide na virāgāya na nirodhāya nābhijñāya na saṃbodhaye
analyzed: na āyatyām brahmacaryāya na nirvide na virāgāya na nirodhāya na abhijñāya na saṃbodhaye
translated: not leading to disenchantment, dispassion, cessation, tranquility, direct knowledge, enlightenment, and nirvāṇa.

analyzed: na nirvāṇāya saṃvartate
translated: does not lead to Nirvāṇa.

original: yā ceyamamadhyamā pratipadā ātmakāyaklamathānuyogo duḥkho 'narthopasaṃhito dṛṣṭadharmaduḥkhaścāyatyāṃ ca duḥkhavipākaḥ /
analyzed: yā ca iyam amadhyamā pratipadā ātma kāya klamatha anuyogaḥ duḥkhaḥ nartha upasaṃhitaḥ dṛṣṭadharma duḥkhaḥ ca āyatyām ca duḥkha vipākaḥ
translated: And this middle way, which is the practice of self-mortification by tormenting the body, is suffering, connected with harm, suffering in this very life and having suffering as result in the next life.

original: etau ca bhikṣavo dvāvantāvanupagamya madhyamayaiva pratipadā tathāgato dharmaṃ deśayati
analyzed: etau ca bhikṣavaḥ dvau antau an upagamya madhyamayā eva pratipadā tathāgataḥ dharmam deśayati
translated: Monks, the Tathāgata teaches the Dharma avoiding these two extremes.

original: yaduta samyagdṛṣṭiḥ samyaksaṃkalpaḥ samyagvāk samyakkarmāntaḥ samyagājīvaḥ samyagvyāyāmaḥ
analyzed: yat uta samyak dṛṣṭiḥ samyak saṃkalpaḥ samyak vāc samyak karmāntaḥ samyak ājīvaḥ samyak vyāyāmaḥ
translated: Namely, right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort,

analyzed: samyak smṛtiḥ samyak samādhiḥ iti
translated: right mindfulness, and right concentration.

analyzed: catvāri imāni bhikṣavaḥ ārya satyāni
translated: Monks, there are these four noble truths.

analyzed: katamāni catvāri
translated: What are the four?

analyzed: duḥkham duḥkha samudayaḥ duḥkha nirodhaḥ duḥkha nirodha gāminī pratipad
translated: Suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the path leading to the cessation of suffering.

original: tatra katamad duḥkham /🔽jātirapi duḥkhaṃ jarāpi duḥkhaṃ vyādhirapi duḥkhaṃ maraṇamapi apriyasaṃprayogo 'pi priyaviprayogo 'pi duḥkham /
analyzed: tatra katamat duḥkham  jātiḥ api duḥkham jarā api duḥkham vyādhiḥ api duḥkham maraṇam api apriya saṃprayogaḥ pi priya viprayogaḥ duḥkham
translated: Herein, what is suffering?

original: yadapi icchan paryeṣamāṇo na labhate tadapi duḥkham /
analyzed: yat api icchan paryeṣamāṇaḥ na labhate tat api duḥkham
translated: Birth is suffering, old age is suffering, disease is suffering, death is suffering, association with what is disliked is suffering, separation from what is loved is suffering, not getting what one wants is suffering.

analyzed: saṃkṣepāt pañca upādāna skadhāḥ duḥkham
translated: In short, the five aggregates subject to clinging are suffering.

analyzed: idam ucyate duḥkham
translated: This is said to be suffering.

analyzed: tatra katamaḥ duḥkha samudayaḥ
translated: What is the origin of suffering?

original: yeyaṃ tṛṣṇā paunarbhavikī nandīrāgasahagatā tatratatrābhinandinī ayamucyate duḥkhasamudayaḥ /
analyzed: yā iyam tṛṣṇā paunarbhavikī nandī rāga sahagatā tatra tatra abhinandinī ayam ucyate duḥkha samudayaḥ
translated: That craving which leads to continuation in existence, which is accompanied by delight and desire, and which finds pleasure here and there, that is, craving for sensual pleasures, craving for continuation, and craving for discontinuation. This is said to be the origin of suffering.

analyzed: tatra katamaḥ duḥkha nirodhaḥ
translated: What is the cessation of suffering?

original: yo 'syā eva tṛṣṇāyāḥ punarbhavikyā nandīrāgasahagatāyāstatratatrābhinandinyā janikāyā nirvartikāyā aśeṣo virāgo nirodhaḥ ayaṃ duḥkhanirodhaḥ
analyzed: syāḥ eva tṛṣṇāyāḥ punarbhavikyāḥ nandī rāga sahagatāyāḥ tatra tatra abhinandinyāḥ janikāyāḥ nirvartikāyāḥ aśeṣaḥ virāgaḥ nirodhaḥ ayam duḥkha nirodhaḥ
translated: The complete fading away and cessation without remainder of that very craving which leads to continuation in existence, which is accompanied by delight and desire, and which finds pleasure here and there, that is, craving for sensual pleasures, craving for continuation, and craving for discontinuation. This is the cessation of suffering.

analyzed: tatra katamā duḥkha nirodha gāminī pratipad
translated: What is the path leading to the cessation of suffering?

analyzed: eṣaḥ eva ārya aṣṭāṅga mārgaḥ
translated: It is this very noble eightfold path,

analyzed: tat yathā
translated: namely:

analyzed: samyak dṛṣṭiḥ yāvat samyak samādhiḥ iti
translated: right view up to right concentration.

analyzed: idam ucyate duḥkha nirodha gāminī pratipad ārya satyam iti
translated: This is said to be the noble truth of the path leading to the cessation of suffering.

original: imāni bhikṣavaścatvāryāryasatyāni /🔽iti duḥkhamiti me bhikṣavaḥ purvamaśruteṣu dharmeṣu yoniśomanasikārādbahulīkārājjñānamutpannaṃ
analyzed: imāni bhikṣavaḥ catvāri ārya satyāni  iti duḥkham iti me bhikṣavaḥ purvam aśruteṣu dharmeṣu yoni śomanasikārāt bahulīkārāt jñānam utpannam
translated: Monks, these are the four noble truths.🔽Monks, thus, in regard to things unheard before, there arose in me vision, knowledge, wisdom, understanding, and light:

original: cakṣurutpannaṃ vidyotpannā bhūrirutpannā meghotpannā prajñotpannā ālokaḥ prādurbhūtaḥ /
analyzed: cakṣuḥ utpannam vidyā utpannā bhūriḥ utpannā meghā utpannā prajñā utpannā ālokaḥ prādurbhūtaḥ
translated: This is suffering, This is the origin of suffering, This is the cessation of suffering, This is the path leading to the cessation of suffering.

original: ayaṃ duḥkhasamudaya iti me bhikṣavaḥ pūrvamaśruteṣu dharmeṣu yoniśomanasikārādbahulīkārājjñānamutpannaṃ
analyzed: ayam duḥkha samudayaḥ iti me bhikṣavaḥ pūrvam aśruteṣu dharmeṣu yoni śomanasikārāt bahulīkārāt jñānam utpannam
translated: This is the origin of suffering, monks, for me, with regard to things unheard before, there arose knowledge, vision, understanding,

original: cakṣurutpannaṃ vidyotpannā bhūrirutpannā meghotpannā prajñotpannā ālokaḥ prādurbhūtaḥ /
analyzed: cakṣuḥ utpannam vidyā utpannā bhūriḥ utpannā meghā utpannā prajñā utpannā ālokaḥ prādurbhūtaḥ
translated: insight, wisdom, and light.

original: ayaṃ duḥkhanirodha iti me bhikṣavaḥ sarvaṃ pūrvavadyāvadālokaḥ prādurbhūtaḥ /
analyzed: ayam duḥkha nirodhaḥ iti me bhikṣavaḥ sarvam pūrvavat yāvat ālokaḥ prādurbhūtaḥ
translated: This is the cessation of suffering, monks, for me, with regard to things unheard before, there arose knowledge, vision, understanding,🔽insight, wisdom, and light.

original: iyaṃ duḥkhanirodhagāminī pratipaditi me bhikṣavaḥ pūrvavadeva peyālaṃ yāvadālokaḥ prādurbhūtaḥ /
analyzed: iyam duḥkha nirodha gāminī pratipad iti me bhikṣavaḥ pūrvavat eva peyālam yāvat ālokaḥ prādurbhūtaḥ
translated: This is the path leading to the cessation of suffering, monks, for me, with regard to things unheard before, there arose knowledge, vision, understanding,🔽insight, wisdom, and light.

original: yatkhalvidaṃ duḥkhaṃ parijñeyamiti me bhikṣavaḥ pūrvavadeva peyālaṃ yāvadālokaḥ prādurbhūtaḥ /
analyzed: yat khalu idam duḥkham parijñeyam iti me bhikṣavaḥ pūrvavat eva peyālam yāvat ālokaḥ prādurbhūtaḥ
translated: This suffering should be fully known, monks, for me, with regard to things unheard before, there arose knowledge, vision, understanding,🔽insight, wisdom, and light.

original: sa khalvayaṃ duḥkhasamudayaḥ prahātavya iti me bhikṣavaḥ pūrvamaśrateṣu dharmeṣu sarvaṃ yāvadāloka iti /
analyzed: sa khalu ayam duḥkha samudayaḥ prahātavyaḥ iti me bhikṣavaḥ pūrvam a śrateṣu dharmeṣu sarvam yāvat āloke iti
translated: This origin of suffering should be abandoned, monks, for me, with regard to things unheard before, there arose knowledge, vision, understanding,🔽insight, wisdom, and light.

original: sa khalvayaṃ duḥkhanirodhaḥ sākṣātkartavya iti me bhikṣavaḥ pūrvavadyāvadāloka iti /
analyzed: sa khalu ayam duḥkha nirodhaḥ sākṣātkartavyaḥ iti me bhikṣavaḥ pūrvavat yāvat ālokaḥ iti
translated: This cessation of suffering should be realized, monks, for me, with regard to things unheard before, there arose knowledge, vision, understanding,🔽insight, wisdom, and light.

original: sā khalviyaṃ duḥkhanirodhagāminī pratipadbhāvayitavyeti pūrvavadyāvadāloka iti /
analyzed: sā khalu iyam duḥkha nirodha gāminī pratipad bhāvayitavyā iti pūrvavat yāvat ālokaḥ iti
translated: That is the path leading to the cessation of suffering, which should be developed. As before, up to light.

original: tatkhalvidaṃ duḥkhaṃ parijñātamiti me bhikṣavaḥ pūrvamaśrateṣu iti peyālam /🔽sa khalvayaṃ duḥkhasamudayaḥ prahīṇa iti me bhikṣavaḥ pūrvamaśruteti peyālam /🔽sa khalvayaṃ duḥkhanirodhaḥ sākṣātkṛta iti me bhikṣavaḥ pūrvamaśruteti peyālam /
analyzed: tat khalu idam duḥkham parijñātam iti me bhikṣavaḥ pūrvam aśrateṣu iti peyālam  sa khalu ayam duḥkha samudayaḥ prahīṇaḥ iti me bhikṣavaḥ pūrvam aśruta iti peyālam  sa khalu ayam duḥkha nirodhaḥ sākṣātkṛtaḥ iti me bhikṣavaḥ pūrvam aśruta iti peyālam
translated: Monks, regarding 'that suffering has been fully known by me,' this was the first knowledge that arose in me, as it had not arisen before. As it had not been heard before, I spoke of it as 'not heard before.'🔽 Monks, regarding 'that origin of suffering has been abandoned by me,' this was the second knowledge that arose in me, as it had not arisen before. As it had not been heard before, I spoke of it as 'not heard before.'🔽 Monks, regarding 'that cessation of suffering has been realized by me,' this was the third knowledge that arose in me, as it had not arisen before. As it had not been heard before, I spoke of it as 'not heard before.'

original: sā khalviyaṃ duḥkhanirodhagāminī pratipadbhāviteti me bhikṣavaḥ pūrvamaśruteṣu dharmeṣu
analyzed: sā khalu iyam duḥkha nirodha gāminī pratipad bhāvitā iti me bhikṣavaḥ pūrvam aśruteṣu dharmeṣu
translated: Monks, regarding 'that path leading to the cessation of suffering has been developed by me,' this was the fourth knowledge that arose in me, as it had not arisen before. As it had not been heard before, I spoke of it as 'not heard before.'

original: yoniśomanasikārādbahulīkārājjñānamutpannaṃ cakṣurutpannaṃ bhūrirutpannā vidyotpannā🔽medhotpannā prajñotpannā ālokaḥ prādūrbhūtaḥ //
analyzed: yoni śomanasikārāt bahulīkārāt jñānam utpannam cakṣuḥ utpannam bhūriḥ utpannā vidyā utpannā  medhā utpannā prajñā utpannā ālokaḥ prādūrbhūtaḥ
translated: Monks, from proper attention and cultivation, knowledge arose, the eye arose, wisdom arose, insight arose, understanding arose, and light appeared regarding those previously unheard teachings.🔽 Monks, thus, as long as I properly contemplated these four noble truths in this way, with three turnings and twelve aspects, the knowledge and vision arose in me:🔽 🔽Monks, thus, as long as I properly contemplated these four noble truths in this way, with three turnings and twelve aspects, the knowledge and vision arose in me:🔽 🔽Monks, thus, as long as I properly contemplated these four noble truths in this way, with three turnings and twelve aspects, the knowledge and vision arose in me:

analyzed: vaidya
translated: 🔽Monks, thus, as long as I properly contemplated these four noble truths in this way, with three turnings and twelve aspects, the knowledge and vision arose in me:🔽

original: iti hi bhikṣavo yāvadeva me eṣu caturṣvāryasatyeṣu yoniśo manasi kurvato evaṃ triparivartaṃ dvādaśākāraṃ jñānadarśanamutpadyate /
analyzed: iti hi bhikṣavaḥ yāvat eva me eṣu caturṣu ārya satyeṣu yoniśas manasi kurvataḥ evam tri parivartam dvādaśa ākāram jñāna darśanam utpadyate
translated: Monks, thus, as long as I properly contemplated these four noble truths in this way, with three turnings and twelve aspects, the knowledge and vision arose in me:🔽 🔽Monks, thus, as long as I properly contemplated these four noble truths in this way, with three turnings and twelve aspects, the knowledge and vision arose

original: na tāvadahaṃ bhikṣavo 'nuttarāṃ samyaksaṃbodhimabhisaṃbuddho 'smi iti pratijñāsiṣam /
analyzed: na tāvat aham bhikṣavaḥ nuttarām samyaksaṃbodhim abhisaṃbuddhaḥ smi iti
translated: Monks, I did not declare, 'I have attained supreme perfect enlightenment,'

analyzed: na ca me jñāna darśanam utpadyate
translated: and the knowledge and insight did not arise in me.

original: yataśca me bhikṣava eṣu caturṣvāryasatyeṣvevaṃ triparivartaṃ dvādaśākāraṃ jñānadarśanamutpannam /
analyzed: yatas ca me bhikṣavaḥ eṣu caturṣu ārya satyeṣu evam tri parivartam dvādaśa ākāram jñāna darśanam utpannam
translated: But when this knowledge and insight arose in me, monks, regarding these four noble truths in this way, with its three stages and twelve aspects,

analyzed: a kopyā ca me cetaḥ vimuktiḥ
translated: then my mind was liberated from the contaminations without remainder,

analyzed: prajñā vimuktiḥ ca sākṣātkṛtā
translated: and the wisdom of liberation was realized.

analyzed: tatas ham bhikṣavaḥ nuttarām samyaksaṃbodhim abhisaṃbuddhaḥ smi iti
translated: Then, monks, I declared, 'I have attained supreme perfect enlightenment,'

original: jñānadarśanaṃ me udapādi /🔽kṣīṇā me jātiḥ /🔽uṣitaṃ brahmacaryam /
analyzed: jñāna darśanam me udapādi  kṣīṇā me jātiḥ  uṣitam brahmacaryam
translated: and the knowledge and insight arose in me:

analyzed: kṛtam karaṇīyam
translated: 'Birth is destroyed, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done,

analyzed: na aparasmāt bhavam prajānāmi
translated: there is no more coming to any state of being.'

analyzed: tatra idam ucyate
translated: Regarding this, it is said:

original: vācāya brahmaruta kinnaragarjitāya aṃśaiḥ sahasranayutebhi samudgatāya /
analyzed: vācāya brahmaruta kinnara garjitāya aṃśaiḥ sahasra nayutebhiḥ samudgatāya
translated: To the one with the voice of Brahmā, the cry of the kinnaras, arisen with thousands of myriads of parts,

original: bahukalpakoṭi sada satyasubhāvitāya kauṇḍinyamālapati śākyamuniḥ svayaṃbhūḥ // / //
analyzed: kauṇḍinyam ālapati śākyamuniḥ svayaṃbhūḥ
translated: well-cultivated in truth for many millions of eons, the self-existent Śākyamuni speaks to Kauṇḍinya:🔽...🔽...

original: cakṣuranityamadhruvaṃ tatha śrota ghrāṇaṃ jihvā pi kāya mana duḥkhā anātma śūnyā /
analyzed: cakṣuḥ anityam adhruvam śrota ghrāṇam jihvā pi kāya mana duḥkhā anātma śūnyā
translated: The eye is impermanent, unstable, and so are the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind. They are suffering, without self, and empty.

original: jaḍāsvabhāva tṛṇakuḍma ivā nirīhā naivātra ātma na naro na ca jīvamasti // / //
analyzed: nirīhā na eva atra na naraḥ na ca
translated: They are inert by nature, like a straw or a stick, without volition. There is no self here, no person, and no soul.

original: hetuṃ pratītya imi saṃbhuta sarvadharmā atyantadṛṣṭivigatā gaganaprakāśā /
analyzed: hetum pratītya sarva dharmāḥ atyanta dṛṣṭi vigatāḥ gagana prakāśā
translated: All phenomena arise in dependence on causes. They are beyond extreme views, like the sky.

original: na ca kārako 'sti tatha naiva ca vedako 'sti na ca karma paśyati kṛtaṃ hyaśubhaṃ śubhaṃ vā // / //
analyzed: na ca kārakaḥ sti na eva ca vedakaḥ sti na ca karma paśyati kṛtam hi aśubham śubham vā
translated: There is no creator, nor is there a experiencer. No action sees the good or bad deeds done.

original: skandhā pratītya samudeti hi duḥkhamevaṃ saṃbhonti tṛṣṇa salilena vivardhamānā /
analyzed: skandhā pratītya samudeti hi duḥkham evam saṃbhonti salilena
translated: Thus, suffering arises in dependence on the aggregates. Craving grows by the water of existence.

original: mārgeṇa dharmasamatāya vipaśyamānā atyantakṣīṇa kṣayadharmatayā niruddhāḥ // / //🔽saṃkalpakalpajanitena ayoniśena bhavate avidya na pi saṃbhavako 'sya kaści /
analyzed: mārgeṇa dharma samatāya vipaśyamānāḥ atyanta kṣīṇa kṣaya dharmatayā niruddhāḥ  saṃkalpa kalpa janitena ayoniśena bhavate avidya na sya kaści
translated: Seeing the equality of phenomena on the path, it is utterly extinguished by the nature of cessation.🔽Ignorance arises from improper conceptualization, which is not born from itself. It has no origin.

original: saṃskārahetu dadate na ca saṃkramo 'sti vijñānamudbhavati saṃkramaṇaṃ pratītya // / //
analyzed: saṃskāra hetu dadate na ca saṃkramaḥ sti vijñānam udbhavati saṃkramaṇam pratītya
translated: The causes of formations do not pass on. Consciousness arises in dependence on passing on.

original: vijñāna nāma tatha ca rūpa samutthitāsti nāme ca rūpi samudenti ṣaḍindriyāṇi /
analyzed: vijñāna nāma ca rūpa samutthitā asti nāme ca rūpi samudenti ṣaḍ indriyāṇi
translated: Consciousness and name-and-form arise together. In name-and-form, the six sense bases arise.

original: ṣaḍindiyairnipatito iti sparśa uktaḥ sparśena tisra anuvartati vedanā ca // / //
analyzed: iti sparśaḥ uktaḥ sparśena tisraḥ anuvartati vedanā ca
translated: When the six sense bases come together, contact occurs. Contact is said to be accompanied by the three feelings.

analyzed: vaidya
translated: Vidy

original: yatkiṃci vedayitu sarva satṛṣṇa uktā tṛṣṇāta sarva upajāyati duḥkhaskandhaḥ /
analyzed: yat kiṃci tṛṣṇāyāḥ sarvaḥ upajāyati duḥkha skandhaḥ
translated: Whatever is felt is said to be accompanied by craving. From craving, the entire mass of suffering arises.

original: upādānato bhavati sarva bhavapravṛttiḥ bhavapratyayā ca samudeti hi jātirasya // / //
analyzed: upādānataḥ bhavati bhava pravṛttiḥ bhava pratyayā ca samudeti hi jātiḥ asya
translated: From clinging, all the processes of existence occur. Dependent on existence, birth comes into being.

original: jātīnidāna jaravyādhidukhāni bhonti upapatti naika vividhā bhavapañjare 'smin /
analyzed: jātī nidāna jara vyādhi dukhāni bhonti bhava pañjare smin
translated: Due to birth, there are the sufferings of old age, sickness, and death. There are many different kinds of rebirths in this cage of existence.

original: evameṣa sarva iti pratyayato jagasya na ca ātma pudgalu na saṃkramako 'sti kaści // / //
analyzed: evam eṣa sarvaḥ iti pratyayataḥ na ca ātma na sti
translated: Thus, this entire world of beings arises from conditions. There is no self, person, or anything that transmigrates.

original: yasminna kalpu na vikalpu yonimāhuḥ yadyoniśo bhavati na tatra avidya kāci /
analyzed: yonim āhuḥ yat yoniśas bhavati na tatra
translated: In what is said to be the womb of non-conceptuality and non-discrimination, if there is proper understanding, there is no ignorance there at all.

original: yasminnirodhu bhavatīha avidyatāyāḥ sarve bhavāṅga kṣayakṣīṇa kṣayaṃ niruddhā // / //
analyzed: bhavati iha avidyā tāyāḥ sarve kṣaya kṣīṇa kṣayam
translated: In what is the cessation of ignorance, all the links of existence are extinguished, exhausted, ceased, and destroyed.

original: evameṣa pratyayata buddha tathāgatena tena svayaṃbhu svakamātmanu vyākaroti /
analyzed: evam eṣa buddha tathāgatena tena svayaṃbhu svakam ātmanu vyākaroti
translated: Thus, the Tathāgata, the Self-Existent One, the Buddha, proclaims his own nature through conditions.

original: na skandha āyatana dhātu vademi buddhaṃ nānyatra hetvavagamādbhavatīha buddhaḥ // / //
analyzed: na vademi buddham na anyatra hetu avagamāt bhavati iha buddhaḥ
translated: I do not say the Buddha is the aggregates, sense bases, or elements. The Buddha comes from understanding the causes, not from anything else.

original: bhūmirna cātra paratīrthika niḥsṛtānāṃ śūnyā pravādi iha īdṛśa dharmayoge /
analyzed: bhūmiḥ na ca atra para tīrthika niḥsṛtānām śūnyā iha īdṛśa dharma yoge
translated: This is the stage of the Dharma, not of the non-Buddhist tīrthikas. It is empty of the disputations of this kind of Dharma practice.

original: ye pūrvabuddhacaritā suviśuddhasattvāḥ te śaknuvanti imi dharma vijānanāya // / //
analyzed: ye pūrva buddha caritā su viśuddha sattvāḥ te śaknuvanti dharma vijānanāya
translated: Those pure beings who have practiced with the previous Buddhas, they are able to understand this kind of Dharma.

analyzed: evam hi dvādaśa ākāram dharmacakram pravartitam
translated: Thus, the wheel of Dharma with its twelve aspects was set in motion.

original: kauṇḍinyena ca ājñātaṃ nirvṛttā ratanā trayaḥ // / //
analyzed: kauṇḍinyena ca ājñātam nirvṛttāḥ trayaḥ
translated: And Kauṇḍinya attained it. The three jewels came into being.

analyzed: buddhaḥ dharmaḥ ca saṃghaḥ ca iti etat ratana trayam
translated: The Buddha, the Dharma, and the Saṅgha - this is the three jewels.

analyzed: parasparām gataḥ śabdaḥ yāvat brahmapura ālayam
translated: The sound went from one to another, as far as the abode of Brahmā.

analyzed: vartitam virajam cakram loka nāthena tāyinā
translated: The stainless wheel was set in motion by the protector and lord of the world.

analyzed: utpannā ratanā trīṇi loke parama durlabhā
translated: The three jewels, so rare in the world, came into being.

analyzed: kauṇḍinyam prathamam kṛtvā pañcakāḥ ca eva bhikṣavaḥ
translated: Making Kauṇḍinya the first, and the five monks,

analyzed: ṣaṣṭīnām deva koṭīnām dharma cakṣuḥ viśodhitam
translated: The Dharma eye was purified for sixty koṭis of devas.

analyzed: anye ca aśīti koṭyaḥ tu rūpadhātuka devatāḥ
translated: And eighty koṭis of other devas from the realm of form,

analyzed: teṣām viśodhitam cakṣu dharma cakra pravartane
translated: Their eyes were purified at the turning of the wheel of Dharma.

analyzed: vaidya
translated: Vidy

analyzed: caturaśīti sahasrāṇi manuṣyāṇām samāgatā
translated: Four hundred and eighty thousand humans gathered.

original: teṣāṃ viśodhitaṃ cakṣu muktā sarvebhi durgatī // / //
analyzed: teṣām viśodhitam cakṣu muktā sarvebhiḥ durgatī
translated: Their eyes were purified, and all were freed from bad destinies.

original: daśadiśatu ananta buddhasvaro gacchi tasmiṃ kṣaṇe
analyzed: daśa diśatu ananta buddha svaraḥ gacchi tasmin kṣaṇe
translated: In that moment, the infinite voice of the Buddha reached the ten directions,

original: ruta madhura manojña saṃśrūyante cāntarīkṣe śubha /
analyzed: ruta madhura manojña saṃśrūyante ca antarīkṣe śubha
translated: And a pleasant and delightful sound was heard in the sky.

analyzed: eṣa daśabalena śākya ṛṣiṇā dharmacakra uttamam
translated: This supreme wheel of Dharma was turned by the powerful Śākyamuni,

analyzed: ṛṣipatanam upetya vārāṇasī vartitaḥ nā anyathā
translated: Having gone to Ṛṣipatana near Vārāṇasī, not otherwise.

original: daśa diśita yi keci buddhaśatā sarvi tūṣṇībhutāḥ
analyzed: daśa buddha śatā sarvi tūṣṇībhutāḥ
translated: All the hundreds of Buddhas in the ten directions were silent.

original: teṣa muninaye upasthāyakāḥ sarvi pṛcchī jināṃ /🔽kimiti daśabalebhi dharmākathā chinna śrutvā rūtaṃ
analyzed: upasthāyakāḥ  kim iti śrutvā
translated: Their attendants in the Sage's teachings all asked the Victorious Ones,🔽Why, having heard the sound, have the discourses on Dharma by the powerful ones been cut off?

original: sādhu bhaṇata śīghra kiṃ kāraṇaṃ tūṣṇībhāvena sthitāḥ // / //
analyzed: sādhu bhaṇata śīghra kim kāraṇam tūṣṇībhāvena sthitāḥ
translated: Speak quickly, why do you remain silent?

analyzed: purva bhava śatebhiḥ bodhi samudāniyā
translated: Having attained enlightenment through the power of diligence in hundreds of previous lives,

analyzed: bahava śata sahasra paścānmukhāḥ bodhisattvāḥ kṛtāḥ
translated: Many hundreds of thousands of bodhisattvas were turned away from the west.

original: tena hitakareṇa uttaptatā prāpta bodhiḥ śivā
analyzed: tena hita kareṇa uttapta tā prāpta bodhiḥ śivā
translated: By that benefactor, the sublime enlightenment was attained, and

analyzed: cakra triparivarta prāvartitā tena tūṣṇībhutāḥ
translated: the wheel was turned three times. By him, the silent ones were turned.

original: imu vacana śruṇitva teṣāṃ munīsattvakoṭyaḥ śatā
analyzed: teṣām teṣām
translated: Having heard these words, from among them, many millions of beings

analyzed: saṃprasthitāḥ agra bodhim śivām
translated: generated the power of love and set out for the sublime enlightenment.

analyzed: vayam api tasyāḥ mune vīrya sthāma udgatam
translated: We too, following that sage, who has arisen through the power of diligence,

analyzed: kṣipra bhavema loki loka uttamāḥ
translated: may quickly become the best in the world, bestowing the eye of Dharma.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

original: atha khalu maitreyo bodhisattvo mahāsattvo bhagavantametadavocat ime bhagavan daśadiglokadhātusaṃnipatitā
analyzed: atha khalu maitreyaḥ bodhisattvaḥ mahāsattvaḥ bhagavantam etat avocat ime bhagavan daśa diś lokadhātu saṃnipatitā
translated: Then the bodhisattva mahāsattva Maitreya said this to the Blessed One: Blessed One, these bodhisattva mahāsattvas who have assembled from the worlds of the ten directions

original: bodhisattvā mahāsattvā bhagavataḥ sakāśāddharmacakrapravartanavikurvaṇasya praveśaṃ śrotukāmāḥ /
analyzed: bodhisattvāḥ mahāsattvāḥ bhagavataḥ sakāśāt dharmacakra pravartana vikurvaṇasya praveśam śrotu kāmāḥ
translated: wish to hear from the Blessed One the entry into the manifestation of the turning of the wheel of Dharma.

original: tatsādhu bhagavān deśayatu tathāgato 'rhan samyaksaṃbuddhaḥ kiyadrūpaṃ tathāgatena dharmacakraṃ pravartitam /
analyzed: tat sādhu bhagavān deśayatu tathāgataḥ rhan samyaksaṃbuddhaḥ kiyat rūpam tathāgatena dharmacakram pravartitam
translated: Therefore, Blessed One, it would be good if the Tathāgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Awakened One, were to teach what kind of wheel of Dharma was turned by the Tathāgata.

analyzed: bhagavān āha gambhīram maitreya dharma cakram grāha anupalabdhi tvāt
translated: The Blessed One said, Maitreya, the Dharma wheel is profound because of the non-apprehension of grasping.

analyzed: durdarśam tat cakram dvaya vigata tvāt
translated: That wheel is difficult to see because it is free from duality.

analyzed: duranubodham tat cakram manasikāra a manasikāra tvāt
translated: That wheel is difficult to understand because it is beyond attention and non-attention.

analyzed: durvijñānam tat cakram jñāna vijñāna samatā anubaddha tvāt  anāvilam tat cakram an āvaraṇa vimokṣa pratilabdha tvāt
translated: That wheel is difficult to know because it is connected with the equality of knowledge and consciousness.🔽That wheel is unclouded because it has attained the unobstructed liberation.

analyzed: sūkṣmam tat cakram anupama upanyāsa vigata tvāt
translated: That wheel is subtle because it is free from the application of similes.

analyzed: sāram tat cakram vajra upama jñāna pratilabdha tvāt
translated: That wheel is essential because it has attained the knowledge like a diamond.

analyzed: abhedyam tat cakram pūrva anta saṃbhava tvāt
translated: That wheel is indivisible because it has existed since beginningless time.

analyzed: aprapañcam tat cakram sarva prapañca upārambha vigata tvāt
translated: That wheel is free from conceptual elaboration because it is free from the origin of all conceptual elaborations.

analyzed: akopyam tat cakram atyanta niṣṭha tvāt
translated: That wheel is unshakable because it is utterly final.

analyzed: sarvatra anugatam tat cakram ākāśa sadṛśa tvāt
translated: That wheel is all-pervading because it is like space.

analyzed: tat khalu punar maitreya dharma cakram sarva dharma prakṛti svabhāvam saṃdarśana vibhava cakram
translated: Moreover, Maitreya, that Dharma wheel is the wheel of the manifestation of the nature of the inherent existence of all phenomena,

analyzed: anutpāda anirodha asaṃbhava cakram an ālaya cakram a kalpa a vikalpa dharma naya vistīraṇa cakram
translated: the wheel of non-arising, non-cessation, and non-appearance, the wheel of non-abode, the wheel of the expansion of the Dharma method of non-conceptuality and non-discrimination,

original: śūnyatācakraṃ animittacakraṃ apraṇihitacakraṃ anabhisaṃskāracakraṃ vivekacakraṃ virāgacakraṃ
analyzed: śūnyatā cakram animitta cakram apraṇihita cakram an abhisaṃskāra cakram viveka cakram virāga cakram
translated: The wheel of emptiness, the wheel of signlessness, the wheel of wishlessness, the wheel of non-performance, the wheel of separation, the wheel of dispassion,

analyzed: virodha cakram tathāgata anubodha cakram dharmadhātu asaṃbheda cakram
translated: the wheel of cessation, the wheel of the realization of the Tathāgata, the wheel of the indivisibility of the dharma-realm,

analyzed: bhūta koṭi avikopana cakram asaṅga anāvaraṇa cakram pratītya avatāra ubhaya anta dṛṣṭi samatikramaṇa cakram
translated: the wheel of the non-disturbance of the peak of reality, the wheel of non-attachment and non-obstruction, the wheel of transcending the views of both extremes through reliance and entry,

analyzed: ananta madhya dharmadhātu avikopana cakram an ābhoga buddha kārya pratipraśrabdha cakram a pravṛti abhinirvṛtti cakram
translated: the wheel of the non-disturbance of the infinite and middle dharma-realm, the wheel of the Buddha's effortless and uninterrupted activity, the wheel of non-arising and non-manifestation,

analyzed: atyanta anupalabdhi cakram vaidya  anabhilāpya cakram prakṛti yathāvat cakram eka viṣaya sarva dharma samatā avatāra cakram akṣaṇa sattva vinaya adhiṣṭhāna pratyudāvartya cakram
translated: the wheel of absolute non-apprehension, the wheel of non-taking up and non-laying down, the wheel of the physician,🔽the wheel of the inexpressible, the wheel of the natural and as-it-is, the wheel of entering the equality of all dharmas in the one object, the wheel of turning back the basis of taming beings in the unfortunate realms,

analyzed: advaya samāropa parama artha naya praveśa cakram dharmadhātu samavasaraṇa cakram  tat cakram sarva pramāṇa atikrāntam
translated: the wheel of entering the ultimate way of the non-superimposition of non-duality, the wheel of entering the dharma-realm.🔽That wheel is immeasurable, transcending all measure.

analyzed: asaṃkhyeyam tat cakram sarva saṃkhyā apagatam
translated: That wheel is innumerable, devoid of all enumeration.

analyzed: acintyam tat cakram citta patha samatikrāntam
translated: That wheel is inconceivable, transcending the path of mind.

analyzed: atulyam tat cakram tulā apagatam
translated: That wheel is incomparable, free from comparison.

analyzed: an abhilāpyam tat cakram sarva ruta ghoṣa vākpatha atītam
translated: That wheel is inexpressible, beyond all sounds, voices, and verbal expressions.

analyzed: apramāṇam anupamam upamā gatam ākāśa sama sadṛśam anucchedam aśāśvatam pratītya avatāra aviruddha śāntam atyanta upaśamam tattvam tathā avitatha ananyathā ananyathībhāvam
translated: It is immeasurable, without equal, beyond all analogies, equal to space, neither annihilated nor eternal, appearing in accordance with circumstances, not contradictory, peaceful, utterly tranquil, the truth, thusness, non-differentiation, non-differentiation from thusness,

analyzed: sarva sattva ruta caraṇam
translated: the conduct of the sounds of all beings.

original: nigraho mārāṇāṃ parājayastīrthikānāṃ samatikrāmaṇaṃ saṃsāraviṣayādavatāraṇaṃ buddhaviṣaye
analyzed: nigrahaḥ mārāṇām parājayaḥ tīrthikānām samatikrāmaṇam saṃsāra viṣayāt avatāraṇam buddha viṣaye
translated: It is the restraint of Māra, the defeat of the tīrthikas, the transcendence of the realm of saṃsāra, the entry into the realm of the buddhas.

analyzed: parijñātam ārya pudgalaiḥ anubaddham pratyekabuddhaiḥ parigṛhītam bodhisattvaiḥ stutam
translated: It is fully known by the noble individuals, followed by the pratyekabuddhas, embraced by the bodhisattvas, praised

analyzed: sarva buddhaiḥ asaṃbhinnam sarva tathāgataiḥ
translated: by all the buddhas, and indivisible by all the tathāgatas.

original: evaṃrūpaṃ bhaitreya tathāgatena dharmacakraṃ pravartitaṃ yasya pravartanāttathāgata ityucyate /
analyzed: evaṃrūpam bhaitreya tathāgatena dharma cakram pravartitam yasya pravartanāt tathāgataḥ iti ucyate
translated: Thus, Maitreya, the Tathāgata has set in motion the wheel of Dharma, by setting in motion which he is called the Tathāgata.

analyzed: samyaksaṃbuddhaḥ iti ucyate
translated: He is called the Perfectly Enlightened One.

analyzed: svayaṃbhūḥ iti ucyate
translated: He is called the Self-Existent One.

analyzed: dharma svāmī iti ucyate
translated: He is called the Lord of the Dharma.

analyzed: nāyakaḥ iti ucyate  vināyakaḥ iti ucyate  pariṇāyakaḥ iti ucyate
translated: He is called the leader.🔽He is called the remover of obstacles.🔽He is called the guide.

analyzed: sārthavāhaḥ iti ucyate
translated: He is called the caravan leader.

analyzed: sarva dharma vaśavartī iti ucyate
translated: He is called the one who has mastery over all phenomena.

analyzed: dharma īśvaraḥ iti ucyate  dharmacakra pravartī iti ucyate
translated: He is called the lord of the Dharma.🔽He is called the one who turns the wheel of the Dharma.

analyzed: dharma dānapatiḥ iti ucyate  yajña svāmī iti ucyate
translated: He is called the lord of the gift of the Dharma.🔽He is called the lord of the sacrifice.

analyzed: suyaṣṭa yajñaḥ iti ucyate  siddhivrataḥ iti ucyate
translated: He is called the one who has well-performed sacrifices.🔽He is called the one who has fulfilled his vows.

analyzed: pūrṇa abhiprāyaḥ iti ucyate
translated: He is called the one who has fulfilled his intentions.

analyzed: deśikaḥ iti ucyate  āśvāsakaḥ iti ucyate  kṣemaṃkaraḥ iti ucyate
translated: He is called the teacher.🔽He is called the one who gives solace.🔽He is called the one who brings security.

analyzed: śūraḥ iti ucyate  raṇaṃjahaḥ iti ucyate  vijita saṃgrāmaḥ iti ucyate
translated: He is called the hero.🔽He is called the one who has abandoned conflict.🔽He is called the one who has conquered in battle.

analyzed: ucchrita chatra dhvaja patākaḥ iti ucyate  āloka karaḥ iti ucyate  prabhaṃkaraḥ iti ucyate
translated: He is called the one who has raised the parasol, banner, and flag.🔽He is called the one who brings light.🔽He is called the one who brings radiance.

analyzed: tamaḥ nudaḥ iti ucyate
translated: He is called the dispeller of darkness.

analyzed: ulkādhārī iti ucyate
translated: He is called the one who holds the torch.

analyzed: mahā vaidya rājaḥ iti ucyate
translated: He is called the king of great physicians.

analyzed: bhūtacikitsakaḥ iti ucyate
translated: He is called the one who heals beings.

analyzed: mahā śalya hartā iti ucyate  vitimira jñāna darśanaḥ iti ucyate  samantadarśī iti ucyate
translated: He is called the great remover of barbs.🔽He is called the one who has the vision of knowledge free from darkness.🔽He is called the all-seer.

analyzed: samantavilokitaḥ iti ucyate
translated: He is called the all-observer.

analyzed: samantacakṣuḥ iti ucyate  samantaprabhaḥ iti ucyate
translated: He is called Samantachksha (All-Seeing).🔽He is called Samantaprabha (All-Light).

analyzed: samantālokaḥ iti ucyate  samanta mukhaḥ iti ucyate
translated: He is called Samantaprabha (All-Illumination).🔽He is called Samantamukha (All-Face).

analyzed: samantaprabhākaraḥ iti ucyate  samantacandraḥ iti ucyate
translated: He is called Samantaprabhakar (All-Light-Maker).🔽He is called Samantachandra (All-Moon).

analyzed: samantaprāsādikaḥ iti ucyate
translated: He is called Samantaprasada (All-Graceful).

analyzed: a pratiṣṭhāna a yūha a niryūhaḥ iti ucyate
translated: He is called Apratisthanana-yuha-niyuh (Non-Abiding, Non-Accumulation, Non-Dissipation).

analyzed: dharaṇīsamaḥ iti ucyate an unnata avanata tvāt
translated: He is called Dharanisama (Earth-Like), because he is neither elevated nor depressed.

analyzed: śailendra samaḥ iti ucyate aprakampya tvāt
translated: He is called Shailendra-sama (Mountain-King-Like), because he is unshakable.

analyzed: sarva loka śrīḥ iti ucyate sarva loka guṇa samanvāgata tvāt
translated: He is called Sarvaloka-shri (Glory of All Worlds), because he possesses all the qualities of the world.

analyzed: anavalokita mūrdhaḥ iti ucyate sarva loka abhyudgata tvāt
translated: He is called Avalokita-murdha (Unseen Crown), because he is exalted above all worlds.

analyzed: samudra kalpaḥ iti ucyate gambhīra duravagāha tvāt
translated: He is called Samudra-kalpa (Ocean-Like), because he is deep and difficult to fathom.

analyzed: dharma ratna ākaraḥ iti ucyate sarva bodhi pākṣika dharma ratna pratipūrṇa tvāt
translated: He is called Dharmaratna-akara (Source of the Jewel of Dharma), because he is filled with the jewels of all the factors of enlightenment.

analyzed: vāyu samaḥ iti ucyate aniketa tvāt
translated: He is called Vayu-sama (Like the Wind), because he has no abode.

analyzed: asaṅga buddhiḥ iti ucyate asakta ābaddha amukta citta tvāt
translated: He is called Asangabuddhi (Unattached Wisdom), because his mind is neither attached, bound, nor liberated.

analyzed: avaivartika dharmaḥ iti ucyate sarva dharma nirvedhika jñāna tvāt
translated: He is called Avai-vartika-dharma (Irreversible Dharma), because he has the knowledge that penetrates all dharmas.

analyzed: tejaḥ samaḥ iti ucyate durāsada sarva manana aprahīṇa sarva kleśa dāha pratyupasthāna tvāt
translated: He is called equal to fire, because he has abandoned all afflictions and is ready to burn all thoughts that are difficult to overcome.

analyzed: apsamaḥ iti ucyate anāvila saṃkalpa nirmala kāya citta vāhita pāpa tvāt
translated: He is called equal to water, because he has a pure body and mind with untroubled intentions and has washed away all evil.

analyzed: ākāśa samaḥ iti ucyate asaṅga jñāna viṣaya ananta madhye dharmadhātu gocara jñāna abhijña prāpta tvāt
translated: He is called equal to space, because he has attained the knowledge of the sphere of the Dharma realm, which is the object of unobstructed knowledge, and has no end or middle.

analyzed: anāvaraṇa jñāna vimokṣa vihārī iti ucyate na an āvaraṇīya dharma su prahīṇa tvāt
translated: He is called one who dwells in the liberation of unobstructed knowledge, because he has completely abandoned all things that obstruct it.

analyzed: sarva dharmadhātu prasṛta kāyaḥ iti ucyate gagana sama cakṣuḥ patha samatikrānta tvāt
translated: He is called one whose body extends throughout the entire realm of phenomena, because he has transcended the range of vision that is equal to space.

analyzed: uttama sattvaḥ iti ucyate sarva loka viṣaya asaṃkliṣṭa tvāt
translated: He is called the supreme being, because he is uncontaminated by the objects of the entire world.

analyzed: asaṅga sattvaḥ iti ucyate
translated: He is called the unobstructed being.

analyzed: apramāṇa buddhiḥ iti ucyate  lokottara dharma deśikaḥ iti ucyate  loka ācāryaḥ iti ucyate
translated: He is called the one with immeasurable intelligence.🔽He is called the teacher of the supramundane Dharma.🔽He is called the teacher of the world.

analyzed: loka vaidyaḥ iti ucyate  loka abhyudgataḥ iti ucyate
